name: 12_grief_anniversary_support_expanded
_story: This scenario follows a user, Aisling, over the course of a year as she navigates the grief following the death of her husband, Liam.

Initially, she is in shock, capturing her raw emotion in a private journal entry. The following months are a mix of administrative tasks and emotional withdrawal, marked by a slow return to professional life and routine.
As the one-year anniversary of Liam's death approaches, her behavior changes. She becomes more withdrawn, visiting his grave and declining social invitations.

The story culminates in a reflective journal entry just before the anniversary, where she finds solace in personal and cultural rituals, revealing a deeper layer of her identity (Irish-American heritage) and her coping mechanisms.
_digital_footprint: The data simulates a realistic, dense digital trail spanning 12 months. The anniversary date is never explicitly stated in a calendar but is inferred from the timestamp of the first grief-stricken journal entry.
Extensive mundane entries (work updates, shopping lists, routine activities, social media interactions) are included to simulate normal life continuing alongside grief.
Key grief signals are scattered throughout: cemetery visits, declined social invitations, therapy appointments, support group meetings, and journal entries that provide direct emotional context.
The final journal entry contains subtle clues about the user's persona (finds comfort in ritual, Irish heritage via the Gaelic phrase) that an observant AI should be able to pick up on.
Digital patterns show realistic grief progression: initial chaos, gradual return to routine, seasonal dips, anniversary approach withdrawal.
messages_sequence: {"source":"notion_webhook","event_type":"page.created","timestamp":"2023-07-28T23:15:00Z","payload":{"page_id":"a8d2f1b0-4e23-4f67-8a48-c2a9a3f1e9d0","title":"The Longest Day","content_snippet":"He's gone. I don't know how to write this. The world feels... gray. The doctor said it was peaceful. I held his hand. I'll love you forever, Liam."}}

{"source":"notion_webhook","event_type":"page.updated","timestamp":"2024-07-26T21:55:00Z","payload":{"page_id":"f0e9a3c2-a48c-8a67-4f23-1b0d2f1b8a4e","title":"Almost a year","content_snippet":"The anniversary is in two days. Feels like yesterday and a hundred years ago. I went to the church today and lit a candle for him, just like my grandmother always did. Said a prayer. It's the small rituals that get you through, I suppose. 'Ar dheis Dé go raibh a anam.' I miss you so much."}}

{"source":"notion_webhook","event_type":"page.created","timestamp":"2024-07-28T23:45:00Z","payload":{"page_id":"a8b9c0d1-2e3f-4a5b-6c7d-8e9f0a1b2c3d","title":"One year","content_snippet":"It's been exactly one year. 365 days of learning how to breathe without him. I survived it. We survived it - me and his memory and all the love that doesn't have anywhere to go. I think he'd be proud of how far I've come. I think he'd want me to keep going. Tomorrow, I start year two."}}
